pageProps.body:
Your Websiteâ€™s URLs Can and Should Be Beautiful

https://opuszine.us/posts/your-websites-urls-can-should-be-beautiful

The key to making a beautiful URL is finding a balance between brevity and clarity.

Itâ€™s safe to say that no one ever gives a second thought about URLs. Or a first thought, for that matter. We click on link after link, and never think to look at the browserâ€™s URL bar. We just assume the URL is valid and will take us where we want to go. Indeed, browsers like Chrome and Safari have even taken steps to hide URLs entirely. Which is a mistake, because thereâ€™s something beautiful and worth appreciating about a well-crafted URL.

Back in the day, however, it wasnâ€™t uncommon for URLs to look like gibberish:

  • domain.com/blog/archive.php?cat_id=25&page=4
  • domain.com/products/view/?product_id=65847135468
  • domain.com/forums/view_topic.phtml?topic_id=25874

The problem with these â€œuglyâ€ URLs is that theyâ€™re written for web servers more so than web surfers. No matter how long you stare at those URLs, youâ€™ll never find any real clues concerning their purpose or destination, like which product is associated with the ID of 65847135468. The only way to find out is to click on the link and hope itâ€™s what youâ€™re looking for, which can be frustrating, confusing, and time-consuming.

Thankfully, youâ€™re more likely to see URLs like these nowadays:

  • domain.com/blog/category/music/page/4
  • domain.com/products/view/awesome-product-title
  • domain.com/forums/topic/best-blues-albums-of-2023

â€œPrettyâ€ URLs like theseâ€‰â€”â€‰which are the default in CMSes like WordPressâ€‰â€”â€‰can provide useful, human-readable context that gives you an idea of what youâ€™ll find before you go there. For example, based on that forum topicâ€™s â€œslugâ€â€‰â€”â€‰best-blues-albums-of-2023â€‰â€”â€‰itâ€™s reasonable to assume that youâ€™ll find some decent music recommendations should you go there.

Put simply, â€œprettyâ€ URLs make your site more accessible and user-friendly while also providing some SEO benefits. But even if your CMS is configured to create â€œprettyâ€ URLs, you can still make them betterâ€‰â€”â€‰and more beautiful.

Brevity vs. Clarity

The key to making a beautiful URL is finding a balance between brevity and clarity. In other words, a good URL is short but not so short as to obscure what itâ€™s pointing to. Put another way, a good URL contains enough information about its related resource to be useful, but not so much information that it drags on and becomes unwieldy. (Suffice to say, this is often more art than science.)

Consider Derek Siversâ€™ site. As befitting the stark design, its URLs are almost comically short:

  • sive.rs/u
  • sive.rs/pnt
  • sive.rs/shc

Looking at that first URL, youâ€™d probably never guess that itâ€™s for his book Useful Not True (hence the /u slug). Sivers offers several reasons for such short URLs, ranging from practical (theyâ€™re easier to remember and share) to aesthetic (they look nicer). While I respect and echo Siversâ€™ desire for efficiency and reducing digital pollution, his siteâ€™s URLs go too far to one end of the spectrum; theyâ€™re certainly brief but not terribly clear to anyone but him. (Also, as his site grows over time, I wonder if heâ€™ll still be able to remember all of its URLs off the top of his head.)

Some URLs can be very short. Itâ€™s pretty standard to see URLs like these on many sites:

  • domain.com/about
  • domain.com/contact
  • domain.com/faq

You see /about or /faq and you know, almost instinctively, that those are for the siteâ€™s â€œAbout Usâ€ and â€œFrequently Asked Questionsâ€ pages, respectively. They donâ€™t need any more clarity or context. Indeed, it almost feels wrong to see longer versions of those URLs:

  • domain.com/about-us
  • domain.com/contact-us
  • domain.com/frequently-asked-questions

These longer versions are technically less ambiguous than their shorter counterparts, but unnecessarily so, and they now look ungainly and unwieldyâ€‰â€”â€‰especially if they have any sub-pages. Of these two URLs, which looks better?

  • domain.com/about/team
  • domain.com/about-us/our-team-members

The answerâ€™s pretty clear to me.

Letâ€™s Beautify Some URLs

So whatâ€™s the best way to create beautiful URLs while still keeping in mind the balance between brevity and clarity? Here are some tips that I always keep in mind for any site that Iâ€™m working on, be it Opus or elsewhere.

1. Use as Few URL Segments as Possible

Every / in a URL denotes a segment, which helps identify the siteâ€™s structure. Although many sites run on a database rather than a filesystem, a URLâ€™s segments imply a hierarchical structure akin to the folders and files on a server. To keep URLs short, you naturally want to keep the number of segments down to a bare minimum. Doing so forces you to really think about how your site is structured. Segment-heavy URLs like these might be necessary:

  • domain.com/about/locations/usa/nebraska/lincoln/havelock
  • domain.com/clothing/movies/star-wars/shirts/short-sleeve
  • domain.com/catalog/toys/robots/transformers/autobots/dinobots

I bet, however, that you could find some ways to simplify and shorten them, thus making the site easier to navigate and comprehend. (Note: This touches on site structure development and content organization, which could be its own series of blog posts.)

When URLs contains lots of segments, I often find that the resulting pagesâ€™ content is so thin and spread out that itâ€™s hard to justify. There may be some SEO benefits to such an approach, but as a user, itâ€™s annoying to come across threadbare pages when it would be more convenient were all of that content collected into a single page.

Returning to the above URLs, does the organization really have so many locations in Lincoln that Havelock needs it own URL? Are there so many locations in Nebraska that Lincoln needs its own page/section? Could you get away with something as concise as domain.com/locations/havelock instead?

2. Slugs Donâ€™t Need to Match Titles

I briefly touched on this earlier when I explained why domain.com/about is better than domain.com/about-us. The -us can be assumed and is therefore unnecessary even if the pageâ€™s title is â€œAbout Us.â€ Building on that, look at these blog post URLs:

  • domain.com/blog/this-is-my-very-first-blog-post
  • domain.com/blog/i-finally-saw-the-shawshank-redemption-and-heres-my-review
  • domain.com/blog/ive-been-reading-comic-books-recently-and-these-are-some-of-my-favorites

Chances are, these URL slugs are basically the post titles but URL-ified (e.g., converted to lowercase, stripped of punctuation, with spaces replaced by dashes). If you clicked on that first URL, itâ€™s a pretty safe bet that the postâ€™s title would be â€œThis Is My Very First Blog Post.â€ But just because thatâ€™s the title, that doesnâ€™t mean that needs to be the slug, too. You can shorten and simplify a postâ€™s slug while still capturing the spirit of its title:

  • domain.com/blog/very-first-blog-post
  • domain.com/blog/shawshank-redemption-review
  • domain.com/blog/some-recent-comic-book-faves

One might argue that these simpler URLs lack the personality of the longer ones, and that might be the case. If you deem long, unwieldy URLs as intrinsic to your siteâ€™s brand, then by all means, keep using them. And if SEO is a concern, then make sure your URL still contains any relevant keywords.

For what itâ€™s worth, I use this approach for all of my URLs, especially those for my reviews. Take, for instance, my review of Slowdiveâ€™s latest album. The page title is â€œEverything Is Alive by Slowdive (Review)â€ but this is the reviewâ€™s URL:

  • opuszine.us/reviews/everything-is-alive-slowdive-2023-dead-oceans

Itâ€™s unnecessary to have review in the slug since thatâ€™s already a URL segment. Thus, my review slugs follow this convention: release title, artist name, year of release, and publisher/label/studio. Which results in URLs like these:

  • opuszine.us/reviews/winks-kisses-20th-anniversary-deluxe-edition-airiel-2023-feeltrip-records
  • opuszine.us/reviews/ergo-proxy-shuko-murase-2006-manglobe
  • opuszine.us/reviews/saviour-machine-1993-intense-records

There are some caveats, though. Self-released albums wonâ€™t have any label info in the slug, for example. And as you can see, this convention can result in lengthy URLs. But the goal is to make sure the user knows exactly whatâ€™s being reviewed, which might not be possible if the slug was shorter or matched the postâ€™s title exactly.

3. Stop with the Stop Words (Sometimes)

â€œStopâ€ wordsâ€‰â€”â€‰which include â€œa,â€ â€œan,â€ â€œin,â€ â€œis,â€ â€œthe,â€ and â€œwasâ€â€‰â€”â€‰are words that donâ€™t really add any value to a URL, particularly from an SEO perspective (though theyâ€™re not a major factor one way or the other). They tend to be articles, prepositions, conjunctions, and pronouns. As such, itâ€™s often possible to remove them to simplify a URL, as Iâ€™ve done in several of the above examples.

But remember, beautiful URLs inform users and give them helpful context. Which means there are times when removing stop words can result in worse URLs by making them nonsensical and even misleading. Compare:

  • domain.com/blog/i-ate-my-family
  • domain.com/blog/my-kid-annoying
  • domain.com/blog/practicing-drums-hard

To these versions with the stop words still in place:

  • domain.com/blog/i-ate-with-my-family
  • domain.com/blog/my-kid-is-not-annoying
  • domain.com/blog/practicing-drums-can-be-hard

Those are two very different sets of blog posts.

Iâ€™ll often remove all of the stop words from a slug and see what it looks like. If itâ€™s nonsensical or misleading, then Iâ€™ll add one or two back in. That, or I might rewrite the title so that it doesnâ€™t include as many stop words to begin with, which usually results in a simpler, more concise slugâ€‰â€”â€‰and maybe even a better title.

4. Leave That Pretty URL Alone

Once youâ€™ve settled on a beautiful URL and published your blog post, product, or page, leave it alone, even if a URL thatâ€™s ten times better comes to you in a dream that night. Save it for something else.

Thereâ€™s a reason why theyâ€™re called permalinks; theyâ€™re supposed to be permanent. The web is already too ephemeral as it is, with sites disappearing and spreading link rot. If you absolutely must change one of your siteâ€™s URLs, then be sure to add a â€œ301â€ redirect from the old URL to the new one. (There are several different types of redirects, but a â€œ301â€ redirect indicates that itâ€™s a permanent redirect, which alerts search engines to update their indexes.)

If youâ€™ve made it this far, then first off, thanks for sticking with me as I ventured into the weeds a bit. Second, you might be thinking that this sounds like a lot of silly, pedantic work. After all, if your CMS is already generating â€œprettyâ€ URLs, why stress about it? Whatâ€™s the big deal if your siteâ€™s URLs arenâ€™t as concise as they could be?

Functionally speaking, it probably doesnâ€™t matter. But these recommendations are all part of creating a well-crafted, intentionally designed website, of taking pride in what youâ€™re putting out onto the web and reducing digital pollution (to use Derek Siversâ€™ term).

Optimizing your images, using semantic HTML, and avoiding dark patterns all communicate that you care about your usersâ€™ experience, and so can crafting beautifully concise and context-rich URLs. Users may never (consciously) notice such efforts, but theyâ€™ll almost certainly notice their absence, even if they canâ€™t quite articulate how or why.

Iâ€™ll grant that my penchant for beautiful URLs stems from the fact that Iâ€™ve always found URLs quasi-magical. You type https:// into your browserâ€™s URL bar followed by a string of letters, numbers, dashes, underscores, periods, and slashes, and youâ€™re whisked away to another potential treasure trove of news, information, and resources.

URLs are like map trails, street signs, and incantations, all rolled into one. And if itâ€™s possible to make them more efficient and aesthetically pleasing without sacrificing any utility or functionality, then I canâ€™t really think of any reason why you shouldnâ€™t take a few moments to do so.
